instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL is a clock line on the data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA is a data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
This board was damaged from coffee spill. Initially the only thing that would happen when the charger was plugged in was a light on the charger.
I wrote down the components that were damaged before fluxing and heating the areas.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7621</CAPACITOR>
removed <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and pad for 3v42 was gone. scraped a little and brought it back
<CHIP>U8160</CHIP>
replaced <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>
replaced <CAPACITOR>C7137</CAPACITOR>
removed corroded j6100 and cleaned pads

After cleaning those areas the fan turns on and CPU VCore is around 1.69v. I plugged in the trackpad cable, screen cable and ssd and I don't hear a chime nor do I see anything on the screen even with a flashlight. I have no voltage on backlight output.
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.57v
<CHIP>U8300</CHIP> (Pin 1 - <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL>) - 0v (I even plugged in a bare lcd with just the lcd cable plugged in and it was still 0v.)

There are no damaged components around the SMC but there are a few probe points that look like they took some liquid damage.
Also, the battery was kind of hard to pull out and it looks like it had some damage to it but I did all these measurements without the battery plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
remove battery and charger power. keep battery unplugged, then plug in the charger.

does this do the thing where the fan spins, stops, spins, stops, spins, stops, then spins and it turns on?

or does it just turn right on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
It turns straight on. It doesn't do the 3 times on and off. 
What does that mean?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Possible issue with clock area, does it look bad? Try removing the JTAG.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
Yes. The clock area(<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>) was corroded. I removed it and scraped the 3v42 pad to bring the trace back and put another chip on there. 
I already removed the JTAG (J6100) and cleaned the pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: :( <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> has nothing to do with clock. Clock chip is <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Oh my bad. <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and the surrounding area looks pretty clean.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Either bad clock chip or traces/resistors from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to CPU/SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
I measured the resistance on the resistors on the SPI BUS Series page and they measured and looked fine(<RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR>-7, <RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR>-3, <RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR>-3, <RESISTOR>R6125</RESISTOR>-8).

How do I check the traces from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to CPU/SMC

I checked the traces from each pin of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to the probe point next to them and there was continuity. Also every pin of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> was from 3.28v-3.31v except for pin 4(ground)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Not much you can do without pulling the SMC. Was there corrosion around the clock chip? Corrosion under SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
There was no corrosion around the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>/<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> area but there was some probe points that were discolored(around Probe 825) as if there was some liquid damage there. Same thing with the SMC. There was no corrosion around it but there are some discolored probe points(the top of the SMC around Probe 949/995).

Should I try reflowing the SMC first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Sure, as I have no other ideas on this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
I was going to reflow the SMC and if that didnt work I would pull the SMC and check traces. 

Before that though do you think <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> could be the issue? Should try pulling it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: It is also possible, make sure to keep the original chip or file.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: I don't have a reader for the chip so I will have to just keep the original. Do I just replace it with one from a donor and see if it boots or do I just pull it and clean the pads because I thought macbooks don't run properly anymore once you change the spi rom chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: First just swap it to see if it works. But if you don't have a programmer then you cannot fix the ME region.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
No Title

Okay I swapped the bios chip and now the fan spins for about 1-2 seconds then the fan just stops spinning. I took the bios chip from from another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B but for some reason the chip had a different marking on the top of the chip. I took a picture of them side by side(original on the left).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Just a different brand chip. Did this chip come from a China board? They are sometimes erased, so you need to check on the programmer.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
Yes. a china board. I don't have a programmer. Could you link me to a good one I can purchase that can arrive in the next couple of days.

I found this one on ebay for $5. Is this a good one?
[url]http://www.ebay.com/itm/USB-BIOS-EEPROM-SPI-FLASH-Programmer-CH341A-24-25-series-/301443899698[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: $5, yeah that will be awesome. Get  aTL866

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
Okay I ordered a TL866 with all adapters and kit for $95 hopefully it'll arrive early next week. Just to be sure though does that mean that the SMC is likely not the issue here since the fan only spun for 1 second once the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> chip was replaced. 

Also, can I use that TL866 to fix EFI/Bios locked machines? Do you get a lot of machines that need that service?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
No idea if the SMC is good.

Yes you can unlock STOLEN  MacBooks with your TL866. No I don't get a lot of them, I live in an area where I do not need to lock my house or car.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
Okay something weird happened.
I removed the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> chip from my board that I took from a donor, then I gave the SMC some flux and heated it. I then put back the original <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and I plugged in the charger soon afterwards.
The fan this time did the 3 times on and off. I didn't take any measurements and just pulled the charger out. I came back 20 minutes later and plugged the charger in and it went back doing the non stop fan spin.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Crap under SMC? Pull and reball.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: I've watched louis' videos on smc reballing but I've never done it before so I will practice on my donors. Do you have any tricks on how to make sure it the smc is lined up correctly over each pad since there are no markers on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Carefully scratch around the SMC, CAREFULLY!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
I've been practicing on a SMC from a scrap board but everytime I try to pull the stencil from the SMC after getting the solder paste melted they never come off cleanly(I've tried 3 times now). I watched Louis' video and he said to heat it slightly then try to pull it off but that hasn't worked for me. Maybe this just takes a few more attempts to get used to this.

Also, my stencil says 980YFC 0.3mm. Is 0.3mm the correct size because I thought I read somewhere that the size of the balls are 0.25mm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: I never use paste, I use 0.3mm balls. Both should work, practice makes perfect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
duke I'm still practicing on a donor and I've gotten a little better at keeping the balls from getting messed up when pulling from the stencil but I always have a few balls that need to be replaced.
At the moment I only have 0.25mm balls and when I apply a few of them manually after taking the stencil off I can see they are noticeably smaller than the other balls. Is it okay if I stick with them being a little smaller or will there be issues when soldering to the board?

I ordered some 0.3mm but they wont arrive for a few more days.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message: Go with the larger ones they are much easier. Even 0.35 you can use. It is normal if a few balls come off and need to be manually replaced. You are heating with the stencil in place?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video (vcore present)
threads.message:
Yes. I do like Louis' videos and put some some flux and heat so the balls sort of melt and I slightly pull the stencil up with my tweezers. I do have an issue where my SMC doesn't exactly fit on this holder and there is a small amount of space in between so when I am trying to lift the stencil off the SMC comes with it.

I am using this SMC holder [url]http://www.ebay.com/itm/252435209794[/url]
